friend_mood: feeling sad because my friend recently said goodbye to a good friend for a while. She loves her!
your_mood: feeling joyful when I recall the moment I adopted my first puppy.
your_strategy: sympathizing, sharing or relating to own experience, encouraging
history:
friend: I recently bid farewell to a good friend. I miss her
me: I am sorry for your loss. I hope you can find comfort during this difficult time.
friend: Thank you, that means a lot. I will see her ag
me: I understand how tough farewells can be. When I adopted my puppy, it was after a period of feeling lonely. It's amazing how time brings us not just healing but also reunions we look forward to.
friend: That's a beautiful way to look at it. How did adopting a puppy help you?
me: It brought so much joy and companionship into my life, something I wasn't sure I could find again. But it also taught me that sometimes goodbyes are just a pause before something wonderful comes along.
friend: You're right. Maybe this goodbye is not the end but a start of something new.
me: Absolutely! And remember, I'm here if you need a friend to talk to. Plus, who knows? The future is full of surprises, and I'm sure you'll see her again. Stay hopeful.
friend: Thank you. I appreciate your support and positivity. It's really uplifting.
me: Anytime. That's what friends are for. Let's plan something fun to do together soon!
friend: I'd like that. Thanks!

friend_mood: feeling excited because my friend cannot wait for their trip next summer. They have been planning it for over 2 years and it is going to be great.
your_mood: feeling joyful when I remember the first time I rode a bicycle without training wheels.
your_strategy: questioning for details, sharing own thoughts/opinion, encouraging
history:
friend: i am really happy for next year i have a trip planned to go to india
me: That sounds like fun! I've always wanted to visit India.
friend: yeah i have been planning this trip for over 2 ye
me: Planning for over 2 years? That sounds like it's going to be an amazing journey! What places are you planning to visit?

friend: I have a whole list! Starting from the Taj Mahal, then off to experience the Ganges river, and not to miss the vibrant streets of Mumbai.

me: Wow, that truly sounds incredible. I’ve always thought the diversity and culture of India would be fascinating to experience first-hand. It's definitely on my bucket list.

friend: You should totally join if you can!

me: I'd love that idea, honestly! I'll have to see how my plans are around that time. And hey, no worries, I think with all the preparation you’ve made, your trip is going to be unforgettable!

friend: Thanks! I really hope so. It's been my dream for so long.

me: With such passion and planning, I'm sure it'll be everything you've hoped for and more. Can’t wait to hear all about it when you get back!

Through this strategy, I aim to show genuine interest in my friend’s plans by asking for details, relate their excitement to my own desires, and offer encouragement about the trip's success, fostering a positive and supportive conversation dynamic.

friend_mood: feeling joyful because one time my friend took part in an essay contest. A few months later she found out that her essay was chosen and that she won a trip to Washington, D.C.
your_mood: feeling joyful when I remember the day I got promoted at work.
your_strategy: questioning for details, sharing own thoughts/opinion, encouraging
history:
friend: I won a trip to Washington D.C. a few years ago
me: and how was it? did you enjoy it?
friend: I had a blast. I met people from all over the country, visited many historical sites, and learned a lot about how government wor
me: That sounds absolutely fantastic. What was your favorite part of the trip?

friend: Honestly, seeing the Lincoln Memorial up close was surreal. And I got to see the Declaration of Independence!

me: I've always imagined what seeing those historic sites in person would feel like. It reminds me kind of how I felt getting that promotion, just that sense of awe and the feeling that anything's possible.

friend: Exactly! It's an experience I'll never forget. And hey, maybe your promotion could lead to more opportunities like trips for professional development.

me: You know, that's a great point. It's really all about grabbing opportunities when they come. I'm really happy you got to experience that trip, and who knows? Maybe there'll be a chance for us to go on an adventure like that together one day.

friend: That would be amazing. Let's definitely keep that hope alive!

Through employing questioning for more details, it shows my interest and keeps the conversation active. Sharing my own thoughts and opinions creates a bridge between our experiences, making the dialogue more relatable and interconnected. Additionally, encouraging reflects shared hope and optimism for future ventures, reinforcing our joyful moods and mutual support.

friend_mood: feeling apprehensive because my friend felt so nervous going into his latest job interview.
your_mood: feeling anxious when I recall speaking in front of a large audience for the first time.
your_strategy: sharing or relating to own experience, expressing care or concern, encouraging
history:
friend: I felt sooooo nervous going to my last job interview! Nerves must occur in proportion to how badly you *want* something!
me: I know what you mean. Did you get the job?
friend: I did! The company does something that I actually like -- a panel interview vs a series of one-on-ones. Have you ever had an interview like th
me: Yes, I’ve had something similar but in a different context. It was during my first big presentation in front of a large audience. Just like your panel interview, it was incredibly nerve-wracking, but feeling that you’ve done well afterward is unmatched.

friend: Absolutely! Knowing you survived and actually did well is such a relief. How did you manage your nerves?

me: Honestly, I focused on why I was there and the message I wanted to deliver. It helped to imagine speaking to just one person in the room rather than the entire crowd. But I’m so glad to hear your news. Getting the job especially in a company you like sounds amazing!

friend: Thanks! It really means a lot knowing I have support and understanding from a friend. Did you find that the more you spoke in public, the easier it got?

me: Definitely. It’s all about practice and finding techniques that work for you. Remember, you’ve already accomplished something great. If you face similar situations in the future, I believe you'll handle them just fine. Always here if you need to talk or practice for those moments!

This approach acknowledges my friend's feelings and offers support while also sharing my own experience and providing a bit of encouragement for the future. It maintains a positive and empathetic atmosphere for both of us.
